Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. Library. Department of Special Collections
Name.creator: Adams, Peggy Hamilton, $d 1890-1984
Title: Adams (Peggy Hamilton) Papers
Description.fundingNote: Access to this collection is generously supported by Arcadia funds.
AltTitle.other: Peggy Hamilton Adams Papers|~|Peggy Hamilton Adams photographs
Description.abstract: Peggy Hamilton Adams was a costume and fashion designer, editor of the Los Angeles Times fotogravure fashion page (1921-34) and a host for local radio programs (1929-33) that dealt with fashion concerns of the  modern woman. The nitrate negative images in this collection document Hamilton’s career as a fashion editor, socialite and official hostess for Los Angeles County (1931-1932). Most of the images show her modeling high fashion clothing for her Los Angeles Times fotogravure feature “Fashions” from about 1927 to through 1933. Many of the photographs are by film studio photographers and feature clothing by film industry costume designers. As such, these images document the shift from Parisian dominance in fashion to the growing influence of costumes in movies on the fashion industry in both haute couture and ready-to-wear. Photographs by Ernest Bachrach (50) and Eugene Richee (50) comprise twenty percent of the collection. Hamilton models designs by Adrian, Max Reé, Travis Banton, Wanda Kofler, Earl Luck, and Dolly Tree and there are twelve design drawings by Robert Kalloch. Digitization and publication online of these images was made possible through funding from the Arcadia Foundation.

Relation.isPartOf: Peggy Hamilton Adams Papers (Collection 1373).  UCLA Library Special Collections, Charles E. Young Research Library.
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. Library. Department of Special Collections
Description.note: Peggy Hamilton, as Queen Olympia, with her court, including actress June Marlowe (right), another actress (left) and a two child attendants (either a girl and boy or two girls, one dressed as a boy). Peggy Hamilton wears a regal evening gown with empire lines in ivory satin embroidered with pearls and rhinestones, with puffed sleeves and a flared stand-up collar of Alençon lace. Her red velvet train is decorated with large flowers created from gold metallic ribbon and has an ermine border. Her crown is ornamented with diamonds and pearls.|~|A different photograph of Peggy Hamilton wearing this gown and train appears in her Los Angeles Times feature "Fashions," August 23, 1931. pg. H3|~|Hamilton's gown was designed by Max Rée, courtesy of Radio Pictures Corporation, for the Coronation Ball at the Biltmore Hotel in Los Angeles at which Hamilton was crowned as Queen Olympia. Hamilton was the Los Angeles County Official Hostess during the 1932 summer Olympics held in Los Angeles.
Title: Peggy Hamilton modeling a Max Rée gown as "Queen Olympia" with members of her court at the Biltmore Hotel, Los Angeles, 1931
Description.fundingNote: Access to this collection is generously supported by Arcadia funds.

Description.caption: On photo: An interesting study of Peggy Hamilton. Miss Hamilton is wearing a smart black velvet gown trimmed with alencon lace, and chic velvet hat which ends in a small bow at the nap of the neck, featuring the "well-off-the-forehead" line much featured in the winter hats of 1930. Large pearl earrings, also typical of the fashions of the winter of 1930-1931. December, 1930 R 18.

G3.
Title: Peggy Hamilton modeling a Hortense hat and a coat with a high collar and flared cuffs, 1931
Description.fundingNote: Access to this collection is generously supported by Arcadia funds.
Description.caption: Note with negative: This chic hat created by Hortense of Hortense Inc. It is fashioned of black straw cloth with imitation aigrettes and is typical of the ultra and chic style and originality of all Hortense creations. This French artist has found the key note to the artistry and fascinating tilt of the Parisian millinery worn before the World War, and these charming creations are shown by Jean Lucas at his Salon Hortense Inc. in their Beverly Hills Salon at 9440 Wilshire, which is their only shop west of New York. Mr. Lucas is the President of Hortense Inc. 1931. Dec. ...Bachrach Photo....Peggy Hamilton, Hollywood's Fashion Critic, wearing an elegant coat of black broadtail (Parisian Broadtail), imported by Beckman's Exclusive Fur Shop on West Seventh Street. Circular flares in sleeves and one side of coat with the extreme collar add distinction to this coat which is valued at $4000.000. Bachrach Dec. 1931. R.K.O. Studios (image no. uclamss_1373_0152i).|~|Handwritten on edge of negative: RKO-123

Description.note: Max Rée (1889–1953) was a Danish costume designer who designed for films from 1926 to 1935 and was the  supervising director for sets and costumes at RKO from 1929 through 1932. He won an Academy Award for Best Art Direction for the film Cimarron. He was born in Copenhagen, Denmark and died in Los Angeles, California.|~|Peggy Hamilton modeling a hostess gown of apple-green satin, with a bodice of metallic gold fabric. The fitted gown has a train. The sheer bell sleeves are edged with grey fox, and the ornaments are of emerald crystal.|~|A different photograph of Peggy Hamilton wearing this gown appears in her Los Angeles Times feature "Fashions," January 13, 1929, pg. J3.|~|For a similar gown by Max Rée , see also: ark no. 21198/zz002bzz7x.
Title: Peggy Hamilton modeling a Max Rée hostess gown of apple-green satin and metallic gold fabric, 1929

Name.subject: Adams, Peggy Hamilton, $d 1890-1984
Relation.isPartOf: Peggy Hamilton Adams Papers (Collection 1373).  UCLA Library Special Collections, Charles E. Young Research Library.
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. Library. Department of Special Collections
Description.note: A different photograph of Peggy Hamilton wearing this coat appears in her Los Angeles Times feature "Fashions," December 27, 1931, pg. G3.|~|According to Hamilton's "Fashions" feature in the Los Angeles Times, October 18, 1931, pg. H3, Jean Lucas, president of the millinery business Hortense Inc., visited Los Angeles, in September 1931, to announce the opening his Los Angeles millinery salons.
Title: Peggy Hamilton modeling a Hortense hat and a coat with a high collar and flared cuffs, 1931
Description.fundingNote: Access to this collection is generously supported by Arcadia funds.
Description.caption: Handwritten on edge of negative: RKO-144|~|Note with negative: This chic hat created by Hortense of Hortense Inc. It is fashioned of black straw cloth with imitation aigrettes and is typical of the ultra and chic style and originality of all Hortense creations. This French artist has found the key note to the artistry and fascinating tilt of the Parisian millinery worn before the World War, and these charming creations are shown by Jean Lucas at his Salon Hortense Inc. in their Beverly Hills Salon at 9440 Wilshire, which is their only shop west of New York. Mr. Lucas is the President of Hortense Inc. 1931. Dec. ...Bachrach Photo....Peggy Hamilton, Hollywood's Fashion Critic, wearing an elegant coat of black broadtail (Parisian Broadtail), imported by Beckman's Exclusive Fur Shop on West Seventh Street. Circular flares in sleeves and one side of coat with the extreme collar add distinction to this coat which is valued at $4000.000. Bachrach Dec. 1931. R.K.O. Studios (image no. uclamss_1373_0152i).

Description.note: Peggy Hamilton modeling a form-fitting gown made of daybreak chiffon velvet with a flaring train trimmed with sable designed by Dolly Tree of Fox Studios. On the left shoulder is a spray of French hand-made gold thread flowers. The fan is made from fuchsia feathers and willow plumes. The imported gloves have a narrow insert of gold kid.|~|A different photograph of Peggy Hamilton wearing this gown appears in her Los Angeles Times feature "Fashions,"  March 27, 1932, pg. I4A.
Title: Peggy Hamilton modeling a Dolly Tree gown of chiffon velvet, 1931

Description.note: Peggy Hamilton served as "Queen of the Lions" during the 1932 international Lions Club convention in Los Angeles. Hamilton is pictured holding a lion cub while standing next to an unidentified member of the Lions Club and Ethel and Grace Bush. She is wearing a hat and a cape over a long dress. Ethel and Grace Bush are both wearing hats. One of the Bush women is wearing a dress with fur near the collar.
Title: Peggy Hamilton, standing next to Ethel and Grace Bush, holds a lion cub at a Lions Club luncheon, Los Angeles, 1931-32
Description.fundingNote: Access to this collection is generously supported by Arcadia funds.

Description.note: Peggy Hamilton is wearing an Olympics theme gown with  illustrations of the Olympic events (boxing ?, diving or swimming, sailing and cycling) within linked rings on the skirt, a tri-colored ribbon (probably red, white and blue) like that used for Olympic medals crossing the bodice, and the flags of different participating countries on her silk wrap. Hamilton is photographed with California Governot James Rolph, wearing several medals on his tuxedo jacket, at the Philharmonic Auditorium in Los Angeles when Hamilton was the official hostess for Los Angeles at the Fiesta of the Olympic Contestants.
Title: Peggy Hamilton, wearing an Olympics theme gown, with Governor James Rolph at the Philharmonic Auditorium, Los Angeles, circa 1932

Description.caption: Note with negative: This chic hat created by Hortense of Hortense Inc. It is fashioned of black straw cloth with imitation aigrettes and is typical of the ultra and chic style and originality of all Hortense creations. This French artist has found the key note to the artistry and fascinating tilt of the Parisian millinery worn before the World War, and these charming creations are shown by Jean Lucas at his Salon Hortense Inc. in their Beverly Hills Salon at 9440 Wilshire, which is their only shop west of New York. Mr. Lucas is the President of Hortense Inc. 1931. Dec. ...Bachrach Photo....Peggy Hamilton, Hollywood's Fashion Critic, wearing an elegant coat of black broadtail (Parisian Broadtail), imported by Beckman's Exclusive Fur Shop on West Seventh Street. Circular flares in sleeves and one side of coat with the extreme collar add distinction to this coat which is valued at $4000.000. Bachrach Dec. 1931. R.K.O. Studios (image no. uclamss_1373_0152i).|~|Handwritten on edge of negative: RKO-128

Description.note: This gown was designed by Max Rée, courtesy of Radio Pictures Corporation, for the Coronation Ball at the Biltmore Hotel in Los Angeles at which Hamilton was crowned as Queen Olympia. Hamilton was the Los Angeles County Official Hostess during the 1932 summer Olympics held in Los Angeles. The location of this photograph with grand spiral staircase is not documented.|~|Peggy Hamilton ascending a grand spiral staircase, wearing a regal evening gown with empire lines in ivory satin embroidered with pearls and rhinestones, with puffed sleeves and a flared stand-up collar of Alençon lace.  Her red velvet train, 15 yards in length, is  decorated with large flowers created from gold metallic ribbon and has an ermine border. Her crown is ornamented with diamonds and pearls.|~|A different photograph of Peggy Hamilton wearing this gown and train appears in her Los Angeles Times feature "Fashions," August 23, 1931. pg. H3
Title: Peggy Hamilton modeling a Max Rée gown as "Queen Olympia," 1931

Name.subject: Los Angeles Breakfast Club|~|Adams, Peggy Hamilton, $d 1890-1984|~|Cluverius, Wat Tyler|~|Schofield, Clara Isabel, $d 1868-1958|~|Schofield, Frank Herman, $d 1869-1942|~|Taussig, Joseph K. $q (Joseph Knefler), $d 1877-1947|~|Standley, William Harrison, $d 1872-1963|~|Bloch, Claude Charles, $d 1878-1967|~|Fenner, Edward B.|~|Sellers, David Foote, $d 1874-1949|~|McIntosh, Burr, $d 1862-1942|~|Clark, J. J. $q (Joseph James), $d 1893-1971
Relation.isPartOf: Peggy Hamilton Adams Papers (Collection 1373).  UCLA Library Special Collections, Charles E. Young Research Library.
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. Library. Department of Special Collections
Description.note: This photograph appears in a story about this event in the Los Angeles Times on June 30, 1932, pg. A10.|~|Peggy Hamilton, as Hostess of Los Angeles County, with ten admirals and others at the Los Angeles Breakfast Club for a pre-Fourth of July appreciation of the Navy. In front of the group is a sawhorse mascot of the Breakfast Club with a horse's head and tail, labeled "HAM." In the photograph are: Rear-Admiral Bloch, Burr McIntosh, Rear-Admiral Taussig, Rear-Admiral Fenner, Rear-Admiral Marshall, Rear-Admiral Cluverius, Vice-Admiral Standley, Mrs. Schofield, Admiral Schofield, Vice-Admiral McNance, Peggy Hamilton, Vice-Admiral Clark and Rear-Admiral Sellers (this  order, from the newspaper caption, is probably not entirely accurate).  The Los Angeles Breakfast Club was located at 3213 Riverside Drive in 1932.
Title: Peggy Hamilton, Clara Schofield, Burr McIntosh and ten Navy admirals at the Breakfast Club, Los Angeles, 1932
Description.fundingNote: Access to this collection is generously supported by Arcadia funds.

Name.subject: Chandler, Dorothy, 1901-1997|~|Adams, Peggy Hamilton, $d 1890-1984|~|Schofield, Clara Isabel, $d 1868-1958|~|American Newspaper Publishers Association
Relation.isPartOf: Peggy Hamilton Adams Papers (Collection 1373).  UCLA Library Special Collections, Charles E. Young Research Library.
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. Library. Department of Special Collections
Description.note: A different photograph of Peggy Hamilton wearing this gown appears in her Los Angeles Times feature "Fashions," March 27, 1932, pg. I4A.|~|Peggy Hamilton with Dorothy Chandler (2nd from L) and Clara Schofield (R; wife of Admiral Schofield) at an event of the 7th annual meeting of the American Newspaper Publishers' Association. The event was for the wives and daughters of the delegates who were guests at a dinner and entertainment at the Cafe de Paris in Fox Movietone City hosted by Dorothy Chandler. Clara Schofield was one of the honor guests and Hamilton directed the fashion show. The fashion show featured gowns for movies designed by Max Ree of R.-K.-O. studios and Adrian of M.-G.-M. studios. The event was also attended by film actresses. Hamilton is wearing a form-fitting gown made of daybreak chiffon velvet with a flaring train trimmed with sable designed by Dolly Tree of Fox Studios. On the left shoulder is a spray of French hand-made gold thread flowers. The imported gloves have a narrow insert of gold kid.
Title: Peggy Hamilton with Dorothy Chandler and Clara Schofield at the Cafe de Paris, Los Angeles, 1931
Description.fundingNote: Access to this collection is generously supported by Arcadia funds.
Description.caption: Text from negative sleeve: Peggy-negs. from 1375 6 x 13 (f.3). "Peggy with Famous People & Costume Orpheum etc. - 1973."

Description.note: Peggy Hamilton standing on a grand spiral staircase, wearing a regal evening gown with empire lines in ivory satin embroidered with pearls and rhinestones, with puffed sleeves and a flared stand-up collar of Alençon lace. Her red velvet train, 15 yards in length, is decorated with large flowers created from gold metallic ribbon and has an ermine border. Her crown is ornamented with diamonds and pearls.|~|This gown was designed by Max Rée, courtesy of Radio Pictures Corporation, for the Coronation Ball at the Biltmore Hotel in Los Angeles at which Hamilton was crowned as Queen Olympia. Hamilton was the Los Angeles County Official Hostess during the 1932 summer Olympics held in Los Angeles. The location of this photograph with grand spiral staircase is not documented.|~|A different photograph of Peggy Hamilton wearing this gown and train appears in her Los Angeles Times feature "Fashions," August 23, 1931. pg. H3
Title: Peggy Hamilton modeling a Max Rée gown as "Queen Olympia," 1931
Description.fundingNote: Access to this collection is generously supported by Arcadia funds.
Description.caption: Handwritten on edge of negative: RKO-30

Relation.isPartOf: Peggy Hamilton Adams Papers (Collection 1373).  UCLA Library Special Collections, Charles E. Young Research Library.
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. Library. Department of Special Collections
Description.note: Peggy Hamilton descending a grand spiral staircase, wearing a regal evening gown with empire lines in ivory satin embroidered with pearls and rhinestones, with puffed sleeves and a flared stand-up collar of Alençon lace. Her crown is ornamented with diamonds and pearls.|~|A different photograph of Peggy Hamilton wearing this gown and train appears in her Los Angeles Times feature "Fashions," August 23, 1931. pg. H3|~|This gown was designed by Max Rée, courtesy of Radio Pictures Corporation, for the Coronation Ball at the Biltmore Hotel in Los Angeles at which Hamilton was crowned as Queen Olympia. Hamilton was the Los Angeles County Official Hostess during the 1932 summer Olympics held in Los Angeles. The location of this photograph with grand spiral staircase is not documented.
Title: Peggy Hamilton modeling a Max Rée gown as "Queen Olympia," 1931
Description.fundingNote: Access to this collection is generously supported by Arcadia funds.
Description.caption: Text from negative sleeve: RKO-24|~|Handwritten on edge of negative: RKO-24

Name.subject: Lions Clubs International|~|Adams, Peggy Hamilton, $d 1890-1984
Relation.isPartOf: Peggy Hamilton Adams Papers (Collection 1373).  UCLA Library Special Collections, Charles E. Young Research Library.
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. Library. Department of Special Collections
Description.note: Peggy Hamilton served as "Queen of the Lions" during the 1932 international Lions Club convention in Los Angeles. Members of the convention committee honored Hamilton for her organization of the conference pageant and awarded her with a plaque during a meeting at the Biltmore. Hamilton is pictured holding her plaque wearing gloves, a hat with a tulle veil, and a fur cape over a dress.
Title: Peggy Hamilton holds plaque awarded to her by Lions Club for her service as official hostess, Los Angeles, 1932
Description.fundingNote: Access to this collection is generously supported by Arcadia funds.

Subject: evening dresses (garments)|~|gloves|~|net (textile)|~|embroidery (visual works)|~|sequins (spangles)
Name.subject: Adams, Peggy Hamilton, $d 1890-1984
Relation.isPartOf: Peggy Hamilton Adams Papers (Collection 1373).  UCLA Library Special Collections, Charles E. Young Research Library.
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. Library. Department of Special Collections
Description.note: Peggy Hamilton modeling a dress with a fitted, sleeveless bodice and full skirt. The dress fabric is light in color with a starkly contrasting dark floral embroidery incorporating sequins and stitched on bands of netting. The shoulder bows and satin gloves are also in a dark color.  Hamilton is shown against a sharply contrasting background in black on the right and a painting of a street or walkway with ornamental building facades on either side in deep recession (perhaps a movie backdrop) on the left.
Title: Peggy Hamilton modeling a dress with floral embroidery, 1933
Description.fundingNote: Access to this collection is generously supported by Arcadia funds.
Description.caption: Text from negative sleeve: FPL-118 [Famous Players Lasky; later Paramount]. December 1, 1933

Subject: evening dresses (garments)|~|chiffon|~|wigs|~|lamé (textile)|~|trains (costume components)
Name.subject: Adams, Peggy Hamilton, $d 1890-1984
Relation.isPartOf: Peggy Hamilton Adams Papers (Collection 1373).  UCLA Library Special Collections, Charles E. Young Research Library.
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. Library. Department of Special Collections
Description.note: The black shoes worn by Hamilton are also in image ark no.: 21198/zz002bzbfb|~|Peggy Hamilton modeling a lamé evening gown and metallic wig. The evening gown has a dark colored chiffon and net under dress and a lamé outer dress. The under dress has vertical pin tucks and floral trim on the bodice, net lace cap sleeves, a net lace hem ending in a train with ruffled net trim. The sleeveless lamé outer dress has a wrap closure, ornamental bands along the right side and right edge of the bodice, each terminating with a long tassel, and a narrow figured silk trim on the entire left edge of the dress. The dress has a high collar of ruffled net and chiffon streamers extend from each shoulder to each wrist.
Title: Peggy Hamilton modeling a lamé evening gown and metallic wig, circa 1925
Description.fundingNote: Access to this collection is generously supported by Arcadia funds.

Description.note: This gown was designed by Max Rée, courtesy of Radio Pictures Corporation, for the Coronation Ball at the Biltmore Hotel in Los Angeles at which Hamilton was crowned as Queen Olympia. Hamilton was the Los Angeles County Official Hostess during the 1932 summer Olympics held in Los Angeles. The location of this photograph with grand spiral staircase is not documented.|~|A different photograph of Peggy Hamilton wearing this gown and train appears in her Los Angeles Times feature "Fashions," August 23, 1931. pg. H3|~|Peggy Hamilton standing at the bottom of a grand spiral staircase with a man (probably the designer Adrian). Hamilton is wearing a regal evening gown with empire lines in ivory satin embroidered with pearls and rhinestones, with puffed sleeves and a flared stand-up collar of Alençon lace. Her red velvet train, 15 yards in length, flowing down the staircase and spilling onto the floor below, is decorated with large flowers created from gold metallic ribbon and has an ermine border. Her crown is ornamented with diamonds and pearls. Her escort is wearing a double-breasted suit with a white handkerchief in the jacket pocket and a white shirt and tie.
Title: Peggy Hamilton modeling a Max Rée gown as "Queen Olympia" with a companion (probably the designer Adrian) at her side, 1931
Description.fundingNote: Access to this collection is generously supported by Arcadia funds.

Subject: Air pilots $x American $z Illinois $z Chicago
Name.subject: Goebel, Arthur Cornelius, $d 1895-1973|~|Adams, Peggy Hamilton, $d 1890-1984
Relation.isPartOf: Peggy Hamilton Adams Papers (Collection 1373).  UCLA Library Special Collections, Charles E. Young Research Library.
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. Library. Department of Special Collections
Description.note: Arthur Goebel was a pilot who worked as a barnstormer and also as a stunt flyer for the movie industry during the 1920's and 1930's . In 1927 he won the Dole Pineapple Company air race from Oakland, CA to Honolulu, HI. In  1928 he won the first transcontinental non-stop air race from New York, NY to Los Angeles, CA.|~|Peggy Hamilton with Arthur Goebel at a fashion photo shoot location, a room with a large mirror and travel posters behind them. Hamilton is wearing a coat made from a printed fabric and a cloche hat and she is holding a purse and gloves. Goebel  is wearing a coat and suit and carries a hat and glove in his left hand.
Title: Peggy Hamilton with barnstorming pilot Arthur Goebel, Chicago, 1929
Description.fundingNote: Access to this collection is generously supported by Arcadia funds.
Description.caption: Printed on edge of negative: Underwood|~|Text from negative sleeve: Peggy Hamilton. Col. Art Goabel. 1929. Chicago, Ill.

Description.note: Peggy Hamilton modeling a hostess gown and matching cap by, Max Rée, costume designer for First National Studios. The gown has a wide shawl collar made of ruffled tull  that extends to the waist and a ruffled tulle flounce or train at the hem of the form-fitting skirt.|~|A different photograph of Peggy Hamilton wearing this gown appears in her Los Angeles Times feature "Fashions," December 30, 1928, pg. I3. The photo credit for this issue is "Moss photos"|~|Max Rée (1889–1953) was a Danish costume designer who designed for films from 1926 to 1935 and was the  supervising director for sets and costumes at RKO from 1929 through 1932. He won an Academy Award for Best Art Direction for the film Cimarron.
Title: Peggy Hamilton modeling a Max Rée hostess gown with a tulle collar, 1928

Name.subject: Olympic Games $n (10th : $d 1932 : $c Los Angeles, Calif.)|~|Adams, Peggy Hamilton, $d 1890-1984
Relation.isPartOf: Peggy Hamilton Adams Papers (Collection 1373).  UCLA Library Special Collections, Charles E. Young Research Library.

Description.note: A different photograph of Peggy Hamilton wearing this gown and train appears in her Los Angeles Times feature "Fashions," August 23, 1931. pg. H3|~|This gown was designed by Max Rée, courtesy of Radio Pictures Corporation, for the Coronation Ball at the Biltmore Hotel in Los Angeles at which Hamilton was crowned as Queen Olympia. Hamilton was the Los Angeles County Official Hostess during the 1932 summer Olympics held in Los Angeles. The location of this photograph with grand spiral staircase is not documented.|~|Peggy Hamilton descending a grand spiral staircase, wearing a regal evening gown with empire lines in ivory satin embroidered with pearls and rhinestones, with puffed sleeves and a flared stand-up collar of Alençon lace.  Her red velvet train, 15 yards in length, is  decorated with large flowers created from gold metallic ribbon and has an ermine border. Her crown is ornamented with diamonds and pearls.
Title: Peggy Hamilton modeling a Max Rée gown as "Queen Olympia," 1931
Description.fundingNote: Access to this collection is generously supported by Arcadia funds.
Description.caption: Handwritten on edge of negative: RKO-25

Description.note: Peggy Hamilton modeling a gown and hat worn by Maria Corda in the 1929 movie "Love and the Devil."|~|This gown was probably designed by Max Rée, who was director of costume design for First National Pictures at this time. See also: ark no. 21198/zz002bzg6n.
Title: Peggy Hamilton modeling a Max Rée gown worn by actress Maria Corda in the movie Love and the Devil, 1929
Description.fundingNote: Access to this collection is generously supported by Arcadia funds.
Description.caption: From image ark no. 21198/zz002bzz9z:  Peggy Hamilton, style expert of the Los Angeles Times, models one of the gowns worn by Maria Corda in First National's "Love and the Devil." Bird-of-Paradise sprays adorn the close-fitting hat of jet; while the gown is a creation of black satin edged with silver filigree. The divided train is a late feature and exquisite graceful note.|~|Handwritten on edge of negative: D 720

Name.subject: Los Angeles Breakfast Club|~|Olympic Games $n (10th : $d 1932 : $c Los Angeles, Calif.)|~|Adams, Peggy Hamilton, $d 1890-1984
Relation.isPartOf: Peggy Hamilton Adams Papers (Collection 1373).  UCLA Library Special Collections, Charles E. Young Research Library.
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. Library. Department of Special Collections
Description.note: Peggy Hamilton at the Breakfast Club posing with 5 men wearing suits and 16 athletic-looking young men wearing white Olympic games sweaters featuring a central ornament inspired by the Olympic emblem: a shield formed with one row of white stars on a blue ground above red and white stripes and the words "ALL AMERICA" and men in suits. Two sawhorses with horse heads, mascots of the Breakfast Club, appear in the portrait as well. This photograph was taken ten days before the opening of the Olympic games. The Los Angeles Breakfast Club was located at 3213 Riverside Drive in 1932.
Title: Peggy Hamilton, young men wearing Olympic games sweaters and men in suits at the Breakfast Club, Los Angeles, 1932
Description.fundingNote: Access to this collection is generously supported by Arcadia funds.
